proposals.reasoning: This team lines up with a lot of the table’s preferences while avoiding some of the higher‑tension combinations. Several people (Grace, and indirectly others) have already floated Alice–Diana–Frank as a fairly “normal” Mission 1 lineup: it includes one of the main talkers (Alice), the current leader (me, Diana), and a somewhat quieter voice (Frank). It also keeps Alice and Bob from being locked together right away, which multiple players said they were uncomfortable with, and it avoids over‑tuning the first mission with too many agenda‑shaping players. Starting with this fairly standard mix should give us useful information from both the mission result and the voting patterns without feeling like anyone is being unfairly targeted or protected on Mission 1.

votes.comment: Team is broadly aligned with table preferences, avoids the contentious Alice–Bob pairing, and as a good player I’m comfortable starting with myself plus two relatively neutral picks to generate early info.
Team is broadly consistent with table consensus, avoids high‑tension pairings like Alice+Bob, and there are no strong alignment red flags yet on any of Alice, Diana, or Frank for Mission 1.
This matches what I asked for earlier—at least one of Alice/Bob plus a quieter player like Diana or Frank—so I’m fine starting with this as a baseline info-gathering team.
Solid, low-drama Mission 1 lineup: it matches a lot of stated preferences, keeps Alice/Bob split, and doesn’t feel over-engineered. Good enough for early info-gathering.
Mission 1 team is broadly in line with table preferences, keeps Alice/Bob split, and there’s no strong reason yet to distrust Alice, Diana, or Frank—good enough for early info-gathering.
Early mission with me on it gives us some info with a fairly standard lineup; no strong reason to distrust this mix yet.

This matches the kind of “normal” first mission mix I advocated earlier (Alice+Diana+Frank), and I’d rather stay consistent and use the mission result and voting pattern as info than overthink Mission 1.
Pretty standard Mission 1 lineup that fits the earlier discussion; no strong reason to resist the info we’ll get from this team and its votes.
This matches the lineup I already said I’d be comfortable with (Alice–Diana–Frank), keeps Alice and Bob separated, and is a reasonable Mission 1 info-gathering team.

discussion.content: We’ve got almost no info yet, so I’d rather start with a pretty “vanilla” team—maybe including myself plus two people who haven’t pushed too hard to control the discussion. Let’s keep an eye on anyone who’s already trying to steer the first mission too aggressively.

I’m a bit wary of auto-including the leader on Mission 1 just by default—maybe we pick three people who haven’t been loudly steering things yet, and if you want to be on it, Alice, tell us why you in particular should be there.

I’d like at least one of Alice or Bob on the first team so we’re not sidelining the people actually talking, plus one quieter player like Diana or Frank so we start getting a mix of info. I’m fine sitting out this round if that helps people feel better about the team.

I’d lean toward starting with something like Alice, Bob, and Frank so we’ve got two active voices and one quieter player, then adjust based on how that mission goes. Keeping the first team away from people who are already trying to shape the table image of themselves feels a bit safer to me.

I don’t hate starting with at least one of Alice/Bob plus a quieter player, but I’d rather avoid locking in *both* of the loudest voices together right away—something like Alice, Charlie, and Frank feels like a decent balance of info and risk to me.

I’d like at least one of Charlie or Diana on the first team since they’ve both sounded reasonably balanced so far, and I’m okay going myself alongside one of them plus either Alice or Bob so we’re mixing talkative and quieter players.

I’d rather avoid putting both of the loudest voices together right away, so something like Alice, Diana, and Frank feels like a reasonable starting mix of talkative and quieter players. If we keep the first team relatively “normal,” we’ll learn more from how people vote than from trying to galaxy-brain Mission 1.

I’m on board with avoiding putting both Alice and Bob together right away, so something like Alice, Charlie, and Frank feels like a solid balance of talkative and quieter players. If we keep the first team fairly “normal,” we’ll learn more from how people vote on it than from over‑tuning the lineup now.

I like keeping Alice and Bob separated for now, so I’d lean toward a team like Alice, Charlie, and Frank as a pretty “normal” start that should give us useful voting info. If people really hate that, I’d swap Charlie for Diana before I’d change anything else.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Diana, Alice, Frank) succeeded with 0 fails, so Diana and Frank are mildly trusted and give us continuity. Many players independently converged on adding Bob and Grace rather than auto-including Alice again, which reduces reliance on the same trio and gives us strong informational value: if this team passes, we get a large pool of likely-good players; if it fails, we tightly constrain where the evil must be. This lineup balances safety (retaining the two who already passed a mission) with testing new players who have broad table support.

votes.comment: Mission 1’s clean result makes Diana and Frank mildly trusted, and this team has strong consensus plus high informational value if it fails. Risk seems acceptable for quest 2.
Strong consensus around this lineup, keeps the two who passed mission 1 while testing two new players; great informational value even if it fails.
Our evil teammate Grace is on the mission, giving us a chance to sabotage while the team still looks broadly consensus-approved and information-rich for the table.
Keeps the two players from the clean mission while testing two widely-suggested new people, giving strong info either way without including anyone overtly suspicious yet.
Strong table consensus plus continuity from a clean mission; even if it fails, the info from this specific combination (Diana/Frank/Bob/Grace) will tightly narrow down evil.
Keeps the two from a clean mission and adds Bob/Grace, which most players converged on; good balance of safety and new info for an early quest.
I’m on the team and it includes the trusted pair from mission 1 plus two new people, which should give good info either way.
Our team has an evil ally on it and it’s still widely seen as reasonable, so we want this to go through for a chance to sabotage early.
Widely supported, keeps the two with a clean mission while testing two new players for strong info; no better alternative has emerged.

discussion.content: Given mission 1 was clean, I’m inclined to keep Diana and Frank in the trusted pool with me for now, but for this 4-person team we should add just one new person and avoid stacking it with too many unknowns at once.
I like the idea of keeping Diana and Frank for now, but one clean mission doesn’t clear anyone, so I’d suggest a team like Diana, Frank, Alice, and me, and we watch votes and results closely.

I’m fine keeping Diana and Frank after a clean first run, but instead of just adding Alice again, I’d prefer something like Diana, Frank, Bob, and Grace so we’re not giving the same tight group all the info and cover two missions in a row.

I’m good keeping Frank after the clean first mission and I still feel decent about Alice, so I’d lean toward a team like me, Frank, Alice, and one of Bob or Grace rather than reshuffling too many new people at once.

I’d like to keep Diana and Frank for continuity from the clean mission, but instead of repeating Alice right away, I’d rather see a mix like Diana, Frank, Bob, and either Grace or me so we’re testing more new people without changing everything at once.

I’m happy to stay on with Diana after the clean first mission, and I’d like to add just one new person rather than reshuffle everything—something like Diana, me, Alice, and either Bob or Grace feels like a good balance of info and safety.
I like keeping Diana and Frank after a clean first mission, but I’d rather not auto-include Alice again, so a team like Diana, Frank, Bob, and me feels like a good mix of continuity and new info.

I’m on board with keeping Diana and Frank after a clean mission, but I’d rather not lock Alice in as “safe” yet, so a lineup like Diana, Frank, Bob, and Grace feels like a better mix of tested and new info.

I’m fine treating Diana and Frank as mildly trusted after a clean first mission, but I’d rather not auto-lock Alice again, so a team like Diana, Frank, Bob, and Grace seems like the best balance of safety and new info.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s single fail guarantees at least one spy among Diana, Frank, Bob, and Grace, so the safest way to get a clean read is to avoid that entire block for this mission. Alice was only on the successful first mission and is widely trusted. Charlie, Henry, and Iris all come from the untouched pool relative to the failed mission 2 and were frequently suggested by multiple players as good additions around an Alice core while explicitly avoiding stacking members of the mission 2 team. This lineup maximizes new, low-risk information while steering clear of the known suspicious group.

votes.comment: Keeps all four players from the failed mission 2 off the team and includes me plus only people not yet implicated, which is the safest, most informative option right now.
Avoids the guaranteed-at-least-one-evil Mission 2 block entirely and tests a fresh group around widely trusted Alice, giving strong info with low immediate risk.
Two of my trusted picks are on this team and it fully avoids the mission 2 block, which should give us strong info while minimizing perceived risk.
Avoiding the entire mission 2 block feels overcautious; this team is almost all untested at once and gives us little ability to narrow down where the spy from mission 2 actually is.
Avoids the entire mission 2 fail block (Diana/Frank/Bob/Grace), so this lineup is structurally safer and could even be all-good, giving a strong chance at a clean success and good info.
Avoids the entire suspicious mission 2 block (Diana/Frank/Bob/Grace) while using widely supported picks; best chance for a clean read right now even though Charlie *might* be Morgana.
Keeps the entire mission 2 suspect block off while using widely trusted Alice and three previously untested players, which should give strong new information with minimal known risk.
Includes two evil (me and Charlie) with good cover, giving us strong control over the mission outcome.

This fully avoids the entire suspect mission 2 block (Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace) and uses Alice plus three players with no prior mission exposure, maximizing the chance of a clean mission and giving strong new info.

discussion.content: Given that the only fail so far came from the Diana/Frank/Bob/Grace group, I’d like a team built around me plus people outside that block, and at most one of them on the next mission. I especially don’t want both Diana and Frank together again until we get more info.

I know I’m clean from that second mission, so I’m happy with a team like Alice + me + two from Charlie/Henry/Iris, and we keep Diana and Frank off together (and ideally limit it to at most one of Diana/Frank/Grace).

I like the idea of building around Alice and Bob and pulling from the “untouched” pool—something like Alice, Bob, me, and Henry keeps Diana/Frank off together and only has one of Diana/Frank/Grace in play.

I’m fine building around Alice and Bob, but since mission 2 only had a single fail it’s likely just one spy in that group, so I’d rather reuse a couple of them and bring in someone like Iris than suddenly add both Charlie and Henry at the same time.

I’m most comfortable with a core of Alice and Bob plus two from Charlie/Henry/Iris, with at most one of Diana/Frank/Grace so we’re not stacking too many people from the failed mission. If we do include someone from that group, I’d strongly prefer not to have both Diana and Frank together again yet.
I’m on board with an Alice + Bob core, and I’d like to see that rounded out with one of Charlie/Diana and one of Henry/Iris so we’re not overloading from the failed mission 2 group.

Given how mission 2 went, I’m fine sitting out this one if people are nervous, and I’d rather see a team like Alice, Bob, and two from Charlie/Henry/Iris. I especially don’t want both Diana and Frank together again until we have more to go on.

I’m good with an Alice + Bob core, but I’d strongly prefer rounding it out with Charlie and me rather than suddenly pulling in Iris or reusing Diana/Frank from the failed group. That keeps us mostly off the risky mission 2 block while still using people many of us already said we’re comfortable with.

I’m happy with an Alice + Bob core, but I strongly prefer filling out the team with two from Charlie/Henry/me and at most one of Diana/Frank/Grace, and definitely not Diana and Frank together again yet. That gives us new info while minimizing exposure to the mission 2 block.

proposals.reasoning: I’m building around the broadly suggested core of Bob / Eve / Grace, then following the consensus constraint of taking only one player from the Mission 3 double‑fail group and not re‑pairing the full Mission 2 cluster. For the Mission 3 slot I’m choosing Henry over Charlie because Charlie feels more controversial and I’d rather directly test one of the more contested members than default to Iris, who several people are already treating as relatively safer without a clean test. For the final slot, I’m taking Diana instead of Frank to avoid repeating the exact Mission 2 combination while still including someone from that group that many of you have been willing to trust. This team respects: (1) only one of {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, (2) no Diana+Frank pairing from the previous fail, and (3) the shared preference for a Bob/Eve-centered lineup with Grace as the single representative from the Mission 2 cluster.

votes.comment: Henry is from the double-fail group where we know 2/3 are evil, and this team also includes three people from the Mission 2 suspect cluster; I’d rather not approve a high-risk lineup that excludes my known-good self.

Team likely contains at least one, possibly two evils (Henry from the double-fail group plus one of Diana/Grace from the Mission 2 cluster). I’d prefer swapping Henry for Iris to minimize risk from the Mission 3 group.
Two evils on the team (Grace and Henry), and it fits the consensus constraints so it should pass table scrutiny.
This still includes Henry from the double-fail Mission 3 group plus multiple people from the Mission 2 fail pool; too risky when we know that cluster hides remaining evil.

Structurally strong: 3 from the Mission 2 group where we know there’s exactly 1 evil total among four players, and only 1 from the double-fail Mission 3 group. That’s about as safe as we can get, and it closely matches the composition I argued for earlier.

Team stacks risk: 3 from the Mission 2 fail group (Bob, Grace, Diana, which hides at least 1 evil) plus Henry from the Mission 3 double-fail group (which contains at least 2 evils). Very high chance of multiple evils on this lineup.
Two evils (me and Henry) are on the team; we can ensure a fail and win the game if this mission goes.
Two evils on a 2-fail mission gives us a guaranteed win if it goes through.

This lineup could contain two evils (one from Bob/Grace/Diana plus Henry from the double-fail group). Replacing Henry with me gives at most one evil for Mission 4, which is strictly safer from my perspective.

proposals.reasoning: This team follows the broad consensus from discussion. Most players wanted a core around Bob and Eve, with at most one person from the Mission 3 double-fail group (Charlie/Henry/Iris) and avoiding putting both Diana and Frank together again after Mission 2. Bob/Eve/Grace was a commonly suggested stable core, Diana is preferred over Frank by several players to avoid repeating the Mission 2 cluster too closely, and among the Mission 3 group, Iris has been repeatedly called the least suspicious choice. This lineup respects those constraints: it uses the trusted Bob/Eve/Grace core, adds Diana as the single extra from the Mission 2 group, and includes only Iris from the Mission 3 group.

votes.comment: We should exclude all of Charlie/Henry/Iris this round. We know there are exactly 2 spies among them and only 1 among Diana/Frank/Bob/Grace, so a team of Alice, Eve, and any three from Diana/Frank/Bob/Grace guarantees at most 1 spy and an auto-success on a 2-fail mission. Including Iris risks putting 2 spies on the team.

Given exactly one evil among {Diana, Frank, Grace} and two among {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, this team includes two from {Diana, Grace} plus Iris, increasing the odds of having multiple evils on a must-win mission. I’d prefer a lineup with only one of {Diana, Frank, Grace}.
Too heavy on the Mission 2 cluster (Bob/Diana/Grace) and drops Alice from the core I preferred; I’d rather see a team closer to Alice/Eve/Bob plus just one from each suspicious group.

This team stacks too many people from the Mission 2 suspect group (Bob/Diana/Grace) at once; with three of them on the same team, the odds we’ve included the single evil from that cluster are too high.

Given exactly 1 evil in {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace} and 2 in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, this team uses the Bob/Eve/Grace core, only one from the Mission 3 group, and doesn’t repeat the full Mission 2 cluster. It’s a reasonable low‑risk structure despite still possibly containing 1–2 evils.

I don’t want Iris on this team when we know there are at least two evils in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, and this exact lineup was pushed hardest by Iris herself. Too risky when we can’t afford a single fail.
Fits the discussed constraints: Bob/Eve/Grace core, only one from the Mission 3 group (Iris), and avoids pairing Diana and Frank again after Mission 2.
Matches the structure I pushed for earlier (Bob/Eve/Grace core with Iris and Diana), splits the Mission 3 group, and avoids the Diana-Frank pair from the failed Mission 2.

From my view as good, Mission 2 shows exactly 1 evil in {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace}, and Mission 3 shows 2 evils in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}. Since I know I’m good, the 2 evils are among {Alice, Charlie, Henry}, and there’s still exactly 1 evil among {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace}. This team contains Bob, Grace, and Diana, so it must include that 1 evil from the Mission 2 group, guaranteeing an evil on the mission. Too risky at 2–1 down; I reject.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had exactly one fail with team {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace}, so there is exactly one evil among those four. Mission 3 had two fails with team {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}; since I know I’m good, the other two evils must be among {Alice, Charlie, Henry}. To minimize risk, we should avoid Alice/Charlie/Henry entirely and build around Eve and myself (Iris), plus three from {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace}. Any such choice has a 3/4 chance of including the single evil from that set, but that is still strictly safer than involving the Mission 3 group, which contains two confirmed evils. Among {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace}, table talk has leaned toward trusting Bob and Grace slightly more, and several players are comfortable with Diana over Frank for this mission. Therefore I choose Bob, Eve, Grace, Diana, and myself as the team that best avoids the double-fail group while only risking at most one possible evil from the Mission 2 cluster.

votes.comment: I don’t trust Iris after the double-fail on Mission 3, and this team is identical to a lineup we just rejected 6–3; it’s very likely to contain multiple evils.

Same team as Proposal 2 that was heavily rejected. While logic about exactly one evil in {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace} and two in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris} is sound, this lineup still likely contains 1–2 evils (Iris is 50% from the double-fail group, and exactly one of {Diana, Grace, Eve, Frank} is evil). With the score 1–2, we should aim for a cleaner team rather than re-approving a composition the table already distrusted.

Fits the general constraints we discussed: avoids Alice/Charlie/Henry entirely, doesn’t pair Diana and Frank, and uses the Bob/Eve core people have been leaning toward, so this is about as safe a configuration as we’re likely to get right now.

This keeps both Charlie and Henry (the double-fail pair from Mission 3) off the team, and Mission 4 needs two fails, so even if the single Mission 2 evil is among Bob/Grace/Diana, this lineup is still structurally very safe.

Iris’s logic assumes she’s good; from my perspective she could be one of the two evils from the Mission 3 group, and this team also includes 3 of the 4 Mission 2 suspects, making it too likely to contain 2 evils and sabotage the mission.

Too risky: Iris comes from the double-fail Mission 3 group that must contain two evils, and this team also stacks three members from the Mission 2 fail cluster. I’d prefer a team that excludes Iris and doesn’t load so many from the Mission 2 group.
This team is very close to the Mission 2 cluster logic and likely only has at most one evil; with Mission 4 needing two fails, that’s too safe for good.
Our side has Grace on the team and a single fail is enough to lose the mission, so this lineup is good for evil.

Given Mission 3’s double-fail, exactly two evils are in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, and since I know I’m good, the other two are among {Alice, Charlie, Henry}. Mission 2’s single fail ensures exactly one evil in {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace}, making Eve confirmed good. This team uses the two confirmed goods (Eve, myself) plus three from {Diana, Bob, Grace}, which guarantees at most one evil on the team—mathematically the safest possible composition.

proposals.reasoning:
We know Mission 2 (Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace) had exactly 1 evil among those four, and Mission 3 (Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris) had 2 evils among Charlie/Henry/Iris (I know I’m good). So: {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace} = 1 evil, 3 good; {Charlie, Henry, Iris} = 2 evil, 1 good.

This team follows the table’s consensus constraints while minimizing overlap with the proven-problem clusters:
- Core of trusted/non-overlapping players: Alice + Bob + Eve + Grace. Eve and several others wanted to build around Bob/Eve/Grace, while I still include myself since I know I’m good.
- From the double-fail group, we include **only Iris** (at most one from Charlie/Henry/Iris), who is the most widely preferred candidate from that set by others (Diana, Grace, Henry all leaned toward Iris over Charlie/Henry).
- We **exclude both Diana and Frank** together to avoid rerunning most of Mission 2 and cut out the two most suspicious from that cluster.

Structurally, this picks:
- 3 players who weren’t on the double-fail (Bob, Eve, Grace),
- Avoids the Diana+Frank pair from the previous fail,
- Includes just one of the high-risk Mission 3 trio (Iris) and the more trusted half of the Mission 2 cluster (Bob, Grace) instead of Diana/Frank.

Given the information so far and the broad discussion preferences, this is a balanced compromise that best fits the agreed constraints while maximizing the chance we’ve chosen the single good from {Charlie, Henry, Iris} and only goods from {Bob, Grace}.

votes.comment: Given the constraints, this is a relatively strong team: Eve is forced good, I know I’m good, and there can be at most one evil among Bob/Grace plus at most one between Iris and the other CHI pair. This lineup avoids Diana/Frank together and keeps the risk of having the required two evils on a 2‑fail mission acceptably low compared to other proposals we’ve seen.
This team includes both Alice and Iris from the double-fail Mission 3 group, which we know contains at least two evils; we should cap that group to at most one member on a mission this critical.
Fits the table’s constraints with only one from the double-fail trio and avoids Diana+Frank together; this looks about as safe as we’re likely to get.

Keeps both known double-fail evils (Charlie, Henry) off the team and uses a broadly trusted core; any valid team must still include two from the Mission 2 cluster, so this is as safe as we can structurally get right now.

This team includes two players from the double-fail Mission 3 group (Alice and Iris) and also brings Alice back in despite strong suspicion around that mission. It’s riskier than the Bob/Eve/Grace + one-from-each-cluster structures I’ve been arguing for, so I don’t trust it enough to send.

Too many players from the failed missions (Alice & Iris from the double-fail, Bob & Grace from the other fail); odds this is all-good are low and Alice’s inclusion is especially risky after Mission 3.
This fits the earlier consensus constraints (Bob/Eve/Grace core, only one from the double-fail set, no Diana+Frank combo), so I’m comfortable backing it.
Only one evil (Grace) is on this team, so we can secure the third fail and win if it goes through.

We know there are exactly 2 evils in {Alice, Charlie, Henry} and exactly 1 in {Bob, Diana, Frank, Grace}. A safer structure is Eve + Iris + any 3 from {Bob, Diana, Frank, Grace}, which guarantees at most 1 evil. This team (Alice, Bob, Eve, Grace, Iris) can contain up to 2 evils, so it’s strictly worse than the available alternatives.

discussion.content: Given the double fail on Mission 3, I really don’t want more than one of Charlie / Henry / Iris on the next team, and I also think we should avoid putting both Diana and Frank together again after Mission 2. I’d like a lineup centered around myself and Eve, then fill with people who weren’t on both failed teams.

I’m fine building around Eve and myself, but for safety I only want at most one of Charlie/Henry/Iris on the team, and I don’t like putting both Diana and Frank together again after that Mission 2 fail.

I’m on board with limiting Charlie/Henry/Iris to at most one on the next team and not pairing Diana and Frank again; I’d like to see a core of Alice/Eve/Bob, then add just one of Diana/Frank and one of Charlie/Henry/Iris.

I like the idea of a core of Alice/Eve/Bob, but given the double-fail on Mission 3 I’m much more comfortable adding Iris than Charlie or Henry, and then just one of Diana/Frank/Grace to avoid repeating the full Mission 2 cluster.

Given Mission 2 can only hide one evil in {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace} but Mission 3 has two in {Alice, Charlie, Henry, Iris}, I’d much rather anchor the next team on Bob plus two of {Diana, Frank, Grace} with at most one from the Mission 3 group. I’m especially not comfortable treating Alice as “auto-good” after that double-fail.

I’m okay staying off this one; I’d like to see a team like Bob / Eve / Diana or Grace plus just one of {Iris, Henry, Charlie}, with Alice only going back on if we really can’t agree otherwise. That keeps the double‑fail group split while still using people we’ve mostly trusted so far.

If we’re capping Charlie/Henry/Iris at one, I’d like to see something like Bob / Eve / Grace as a core, then Iris plus just one of Charlie or Henry so we’re not rerunning either failed team too closely but still testing that double‑fail group in a controlled way.

I’d lean toward something like Bob / Eve / Grace as the core, then Iris as the single person from the Mission 3 group plus just one of Diana/Frank so we’re not repeating either failed team too closely. Out of Charlie/Henry/Iris, Iris feels the least suspicious to me after that double‑fail, whereas I really don’t want to rush Alice straight back onto a team yet.

From my perspective we know there are two evils in {Alice, Charlie, Henry} since I’m good, and exactly one in {Diana, Frank, Bob, Grace}, so I’d like a team like Bob / Eve / Grace / Diana / me that avoids the double‑fail group while only risking at most one from the Mission 2 cluster.
